_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The following provides a brief summary of the key components of the Risk Management Plan (RMP) Program for the aqueous ammonia storage and handling system at Reliant Energy Channelview.

General Description of the Facility and Regulated Substance

Reliant Energy Channelview is located in Channelview, Texas in an industrial setting entirely within the property boundary of the Equistar Chemical Channelview Complex.  The facility is an electric cogenerating station consisting of four 170-MW, combined-cycle, natural gas-fired turbines coupled to a single steam turbine for electricity generation and steam production.  A duct burner/Heat Recovery Steam Generator (HRSG) and a Selective Catalytic Reduction (SCR) system are associated with each of the gas turbines.  The SCRs employ aqueous ammonia injection technology to control emissions of oxides of nitrogen (NOx).  Aqueous ammonia is classified as a toxic chemical subject to the requirements of RMP Program.  The aqueous ammonia used in these SCR systems is a 29.7% solution of ammonia in water.

The ammonia storage and handling system at Reliant Energy Channelview is comprised of two storage tanks, transfer pumps, and piping which terminate at the evaporator for each unit where the aqueous ammonia is atomized and vaporized.  The tanks have a capacity of 30,000 gallons each.  The tanks are equipped with pressure relief valves, as well as temperature, pressure, and level indicators.  There are ammonia detectors located on each tank and on the ammonia transfer pump skid.

All other regulated substances onsite are below applicable thresholds for RMP.

Offsite Consequence Analysis

The offsite consequence analysis (OCA) prepared in support of this RMP utilized the methodologies recommended by EPA and employed in the RMP*Comp, Version 1.06 modeling system.

The worst-case release scenario (WCS) considered the catastrophic rupture of one of the aqueous ammonia storage tanks, in which the entire contents of one tank is released wi

thin the secondary containment dike.  The secondary containment dike is large enough to contain the entire volume and limits the exposed surface area of a pool, which reduces the release rate.  Under worst-case meteorological conditions of 1.5 m/s wind speed and atmospheric stability class F (stable atmosphere), the resulting ammonia cloud could travel 0.2 miles before dispersing sufficiently to no longer pose a health hazard to the public.  This worst-case impact distance extends offsite of the Reliant Energy facility but does not exceed beyond the property boundaries of the Equistar Chemical facility.  The WCS does not impact any offsite residences, institutions (e.g., schools, hospitals), parks, or recreational areas.

Several alternative release scenarios (ARSs) were considered including releases due to a failed delivery hose, a failed pipe between the ammonia transfer pumps and an ammonia flow control unit (AFCU), a failed pipe between an AFCU and an evaporator, and a corrosion-caused hole in piping.  The release due to a failed delivery hose resulted in the farthest impact distance (0.1 miles) and is the ARS presented in this RMP.  The impact due to the ARS extends offsite of the Reliant Energy facility but does not exceed beyond the property boundaries of the Equistar Chemical facility. The ARS does not impact any offsite residences, institutions (e.g., schools, hospitals), parks, or recreational areas.

There are two water monitors located near the aqueous ammonia storage tanks, which could serve as active mitigation to knock down an ammonia plume in the event of a release.  The effect of this mitigation measure was not included in the ARS analyses as conservative approach, since the water monitors would be manually activated.

Five-Year Accident History

In November of 2005, a very small amount of ammonia was spilled inside the containment area during a truck unloading operation.  The spill was caused by a weak area of the transfer hose that failed during u

nloading.  The ammonia vendor has since modified its hose rotation and maintenance schedule to prevent future incidents.  There were no injuries or property damage as a result of the incident.

Summary of Prevention Program 2

Reliant Energy Channelview is covered by an accidental release prevention program, which includes the following:
? Periodic hazard review and updates
? Periodic audits of the system and its operation
? Emergency response plan coordinated with local responding agencies

The aqueous ammonia storage and handling system prevention program includes the following components:
? Comprehensive plan covering all components of the aqueous ammonia system with respect to operation, maintenance, inspection, and training
? Internal compliance audits
? Incident investigation

Summary of the Emergency Response Program

Reliant Energy Channelview has arranged for Equistar Chemical Channelview Complex to be the first responders in case of an emergency. 

Planned Changes to Improve Safety

A hazard review of the aqueous ammonia storage and handling system at Reliant Energy Channelview was conducted as part of this RMP.  There are not any planned changes to the system at this time.
